items.message: River levels remain high in the Cottingham area. Levels may remain high on Saturday 25/11/2023 and Sunday 26/11/2023. Further rain is forecast on Sunday night and Monday 27/11/2023 and levels may rise in response to this rain. We continue to monitor the forecast. Avoid using low-lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 5pm on 25/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high but falling on the River Churn as a result of previous heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially in the Cerney Wick area.  The weather forecast today, 25/11/23 is dry, with some rainfall possible from tomorrow afternoon. We expect river levels to continue to fall slowly over the next few days. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated this evening, 25/11/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Aldingbourne and Barnham Rifes
items.message: The Aldingbourne Rife remains high, but is slowly falling. Minor flooding is still affecting caravans at Riverside Caravan Centre and Rowan Park Caravan Park. The Barnham Rife is also slowly falling. Minor flood impacts will continue in Bersted. Frontal rain is expected tomorrow (Sunday 26/11/2023) and on Monday (27/11/2023) but only minor flooding is expected. Water levels remain higher than normal and will rise again on Sunday. The Aldingbourne Rife might not return to normal until December. Some roads will be affected by flood water, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including Shripney Lane. We are running our pumps at Felpham and keeping grilles clear to help reduce the risk of flooding. We will update this message by 19:00 26/11/2023.

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely from now, 8:30am on Saturday 25th November, and for at least the next 24 hours. Water levels continue to remain high in this area. The forecast tides at Great Yarmouth will restrict the freshwater river drainage out to sea, resulting in higher than normal water levels within the Broads until the current high tides pass. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning. The current series of high spring tides will continue for the next few days, and further warning messages may be issued. After the weekend the tides will start to fall away, allowing the freshwater river flows to drain out to sea at low tide as normal. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are closely monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 9am on Sunday 26th November, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Upper Og Valley
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to rainfall over the past few weeks and remain high at our observation borehole in Draycot Foliat in the Og Valley area. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and remain at a level where communities may be affected by flooding from groundwater over the coming weeks. 

Levels are high but slowly falling in response to dry conditions over the past week, but levels remain responsive to further rainfall. Further rainfall is expected over the coming week with low confidence over exact locations and timings of rain. Groundwater levels will continue to remain high and may still impact low lying gardens and cellars. 

Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message by 01/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed. 

River levels on the Chertsey Bourne have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. No further rainfall is forecast today (25/11/2023) in Chertsey. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi Pumping Station is 7.98 m and is steady. The drain level is 7.49 m and continues to fall slowly.
Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this level exceeds 7.30 m, the road from Muchelney to Long Load above 7.86 m, and the road from Muchelney to Thorney above 7.93 m.
The weather forecast is dry for today, Saturday 25/11/2023, followed by light to moderate rain tomorrow and Monday. The River Yeo will likely remain fairly high over the coming days due to pumping from the Moors, and the forecast rain on Sunday and Monday. We continue to pump and operate the Parrett Flood Relief Channel as much as possible to evacuate water.
The situation is being monitored and staff are checking the condition of flood banks, spillways and weed screens. Please refer to @TravelSomerset for information on local road closures.
For water levels on the rivers, please refer to our website: (check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels).
This message will be updated by 15:00 on Sunday 26/11/2023.

items.description: Slad Brook
items.message: River levels remain high due to rises at the Slad Steanbridge Lane river gauge as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid contact with flood water. This message will be updated by 10 am on Sunday 26/11/23 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Creyke, Mill and Broadlane Becks at Cottingham
items.message: River levels remain high on Creyke, Mill and Broadlane Becks at Cottingham. The area most at risk is properties around King Street, Northgate, Dunswell Road and North Moor Lane. Levels may remain high on Saturday 25/11/2023 and Sunday 26/11/2023. Further rain is forecast on Sunday night and Monday 27/11/2023 and levels may rise in response to this rain. We continue to monitor the forecast. Please consider putting your flood plan into action and avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses. We will update this message by 5pm on 25/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

The forecast tides at Great Yarmouth will restrict the freshwater river drainage out to sea, resulting in higher than normal water levels within the Broads until the current high tides pass. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are closely monitoring the situation. items.description: Riverside properties along the tidal River Yare including Cantley, Brundall and Reedham
items.message: This message has been issued because flooding of homes and businesses is likely from now, 8:30am on Saturday 25th November, and for at least the next 24 hours. Water levels continue to remain high in this area. The forecast tides at Great Yarmouth will restrict the freshwater river drainage out to sea, resulting in higher than normal water levels within the Broads until the current high tides pass. Areas most at risk are in Reedham, Cantley and Brundall. Roads affected include Ferry Road in Reedham, the A47 and the railway line between Reedham and Brundall. The current series of high spring tides will continue for the next few days, and further warning messages may be issued. After the weekend the tides will start to fall away, allowing the freshwater river flows to drain out to sea at low tide as normal. Be ready to take action to protect your property if flooding is expected. We are closely monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 9am on Sunday 26th November, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Hambledon
items.message: In Hambledon, groundwater levels are high and rising. Since 25/10/2023, 262mm of rain has been recorded in Worlds End. This is more than twice the average rainfall expected during that time. In the last 24 hours, the groundwater level at Whitedale Farm has risen by 20cm. From Sunday night (26/11/2023), levels may be high enough to affect a small number of cellars in Lower West Street, however the groundwater level may peak just before this occurs. The weather until Sunday is forecast to be dry. On Monday (27/11/2023) up to 25mm of rain is forecast in Hampshire. If heavy rain affects Hambledon, the groundwater level will continue to rise throughout next week. If not, then the level is expected to peak early next week and water could then recede from cellars in Lower West Street. We will continue to monitor the forecast. We are liaising with Hambledon Flood Action Group. Please remove any valuables from cellars, and if you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Wednesday 29/11/2023.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Finchdean, Dean Lane End and Rowlands Castle
items.message: In Finchdean and Rowlands Castle, groundwater levels are high and rising. Since 25/10/23, 251mm of rain has been recorded in Walderton. This is more than twice the average amount expected during that period. In the last 24 hours, the groundwater level in Finchdean has increased by 30cm. From Sunday 26/11/23, the Idsworth Lavant is expected to be flowing through all villages. From Monday 27/11/23, it is possible pumps which prevent water from entering property may be required. Surface water could flood property during heavier rain events. However, there is a chance groundwater could peak below this impact level. Dry weather is forecast until Sunday 26/11/23. On Monday, up to 25mm of rain is forecast in Hampshire. If heavy rain affects the area, the groundwater level will continue to rise throughout next week. If not, then the level is expected to peak next week and water could begin receding. We are liaising with the Flood Action Group. If you use pumps to reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. This message will be updated by 17:00 on Thursday 30/11/23.

items.description: The Essex coast at Coalhouse Fort and surrounding marshland
items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds, but the current series of high spring tides will remain for the the next few days. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton, to and including, Lee-over-Sands
items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds, but the current series of high spring tides will remain for the the next few days. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: Tidal River Medway and Medway estuary
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.
The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this warning if necessary.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Dartford Creek and The Mardyke to the Thames Barrier

floodArea.county: Barking and Dagenham, Bexley, Greater London, Greenwich, Havering, Kent, Newham, Thurrock

items.description: Lower River Medway
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
The flood forecast has changed significantly. As a result, there is no longer a risk of flooding in the area.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: Tyne and Wear coast

floodArea.county: County Durham, Hartlepool, North Tyneside, South Tyneside, Sunderland

items.message:
Large waves and spray overtopping are expected during this afternoon’s high tide due to strong north-westerly winds. Impacts will be greatest between 11:45 AM and 3:45 PM on 25/11/2023.

Areas most likely to be affected will be Seaham harbour and docks and Seaburn lower promenade.

Flooding is possible at beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths, and roads.

We will continue to monitor the forecast.

Stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.

This message will be updated by 5:00 PM on 25/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Stour area from Fordwich to Stonar Cut
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
The risk of flooding in the area has now passed.

We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
